ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Professor also provided additional recorded content and posted all lecture recordings.

On top of having in-person classes (which functioned more as an open-forum to go over concepts, work through problems, etc), the professor would record instructional videos on the material for us to watch before class.
recorded lectures and written notes from Prof

There was a live virtual lecture where we solved problems, but they were always recorded and watching the recording was always an option. There were also some pre-recorded videos for us to watch, summarizing the textbook. This was a flipped classroom where we watched lectures and then went to class to solve problems.
Office hours with Professor Loewenberg and Rodrigo
Pre-recorded and live components.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course taught me the principles of process control: how engineers deal with disturbances in their processes. A very interesting topic that I previously did not know existed.

A whole introduction to process control for chemical processes! This is a really unique class in the ChemE curriculum, and gives an interesting perspective on understanding the dynamics of processes, and then designing control processes to manage these dynamics. Learned lots about LaPlace Transforms, modelling dynamic systems, various types of controllers, and different methods of control. We also utilized SimuLink in Matlab to analyze some of the systems, which was a nice, more practical, addition to the class.

You learn about the Chemical Engineering design process, use of Matlab to simulate processes, mathematic models to describe processes (setting them up from balances as well as solving them and interpreting them).

Many of the engineering classes build off each other but I enjoyed the fact this course was mostly new to us, and we learned how to make the process diagrams and models that are useful for practical applications of chemical engineering and applied new skills that we haven't in other classes such as Matlab and laplace transforms from differential equations.
Detailed understanding of chemical process design (like feedback, feedforward, combinations of them, etc.)

There is a large emphasis on calculating transfer functions and taking Laplace transformations.  You will also learn about feedback, feedforward, and other forms of control.  PID controllers are also an important part of the course.  A simulation software, Simulink, is used as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
One strength of the course is the teaching format. The Canvas page was very organized with all of the necessary resources available to learn the material, including instructional videos, notes, problem sets, and solutions. Additionally, the in-person class was very helpful because it was always tailored to what us students needed help with. The textbook for the class was also pretty well-written, and was helpful in understanding the material. 

One weakness of the class was the pacing. We moved through material very quickly, and it was clear that students got somewhat dragged along at certain points along the way. That being said, everyone got a chance to catch up at the end, just in time for the final!

This course was a great look into the Chemical Engineering processes that we learn about in other classes as Chemical Engineers. I think it had a good balance of pen + paper math to Matlab, but it kinda felt like two separate classes in that respect too. The entirety of the beginning of the course was pen + paper, and then it suddenly transitions into a Matlab class.
I think it is a strength of this course that most of the material is all new to us. And Professor Loewenberg adapted the course when possible so that we learned the material the best we could.
Professor Loewenberg and Rodrigo are the highlights of the course. It is pretty dry, and gets challenging very quickly, but the teaching staff made it work.
This class was taught in a reverse classroom structure, which was helpful, but I feel that a stronger emphasis on problem solving during class time would be beneficial.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded instructional videos were awesome! Super helpful and a great way to take advantage of the Canvas media library. It was also awesome to have all of the classes recorded and uploaded to Canvas. This made it really easy to review materials and go through explanations again in case you missed them during class.

The recordings were great! Being able to go back to review (or watch for the first time if Zoom fatigue kicked in and I missed class) was amazing. At times, I felt as though some recordings came out semi-sporadically, which made it sometimes difficult to stay super engaged, but in the end it was fine. I liked the idea of videos on = I can be called on and videos off = please don't call on me. Part of me also doesn't like this because maybe not everyone can always put their video on if they want to interact with the class, but at the same time our class was small enough and everyone had at one point had their videos on at some point so it worked for our class.
I enjoyed the in class collaborative problem solving activities in the breakout rooms as they helped me engage with the material and learn it better.
The class felt the same online and in-person, perhaps with the flipped classroom structure added.

This class was taught in a reverse classroom structure, which I feel was productive given the material and the online nature.  There were technical challenges throughout the semester, but I don't hold these against anyone since we were all rushed into the new virtual system.  While I hope that by the time the Fall 2021 semester rolls around, this course is not virtual, I believe that this layout performed quite well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to chemical engineering students for whom it is a requirement.
It's a requirement for ABET ChemE's and I've never seen anyone take it who doesn't need it, but yes! would recommend! Especially if Loewenberg is teaching it!

I would! It was mathematically challenging but never too difficult! If you like problem solving like engineers this was a great class, it makes you think but it was taught in a way that felt very fair and engaging.
Yes if you are ChemE ABET (you're required to), and I do not really see a point in taking unless you choose to work for chemical plants in the future.
This class is a requirement for ABET Chemical engineers.  I think it's a good course, as it exposes students to more real-world scenarios and builds intuition.
